title: RIP Latitude Financial, float 'dead on arrival'
text:
While Monday's decision to re-price the float sparked some new interest from deep value funds, it scared plenty of investors off when they realised the new deal still wasn't covered.

And the ones scared off were the growth-oriented funds who are typically buy when a growth-y CEO like Ahmed Fahour and KKR are selling than a deep value type.

So when Goldman Sachs, Macquarie Capital and UBS formally opened the books after market on Monday, the deal was not going to fly. There may have been enough bids to get to $1.04 billion - thanks to the retail offer and $200 million "indication" - but there were not the quality or quantity of bids to ensure Latitude a happy and safe market debut.

There was plenty of finger pointing on Wednesday, in the wake of the pulled deal, revealed by Street Talk.

Bankers were pointing to shareholders (KKR, Varde Partners and Deutsche Bank), shareholders were pointing to bankers, investors were pointing at management and the shareholders. Success has many fathers, as they say.

What's clear is that there were plenty of people driving what ended up as a rushed run at the ASX-boards. It is understood the latest attempt started in the middle of the year when KKR, on behalf of the owners, invited Goldman Sachs to work on the narrative and early preparations, before the wider syndicate and lawyers were called in.

From there, it was a speedy preparation. Analysts were not given long to prepare reports, let alone market them. And one source involved in the offshore leg of the marketing reckons there were plenty of questions about the banking Royal Commission, which probably could've been squashed weeks ago with a wider pre-marketing program.
description: Latitude Financial's IPO was dead when its three brokers opened the books on a $1.04 billion raising on Monday night.
